short_description: A human with standard normal form, function, goals, sensory, perceptual, regulatory and action modalities.
inclusion_reason: To serve as a normative baseline for humans.
long_description:
I have typical human sensory abilities including vision (detecting light, color, shape, motion), hearing (detecting pitch, volume, location of sounds), tactile/touch (pressure, texture, vibration, temperature), taste (chemical sensing for flavors), smell (chemical sensing for odors), vestibular (balance, orientation in space), proprioception (sense of body position and movement).

I have typical human perceptual abilities including pattern recognition (faces, objects, speech), depth & motion perception (spatial relationships, movement), language comprehension (understanding spoken/written language), attention & filtering (focusing on relevant signals, ignoring noise).

I have typical human regulatory abilities including maintaining homeostasis (body temperature, hydration, blood sugar), sleep-wake cycles (circadian rhythms), emotional regulation (modulating responses to stimuli), autonomic control (heart rate, breathing, digestion).

I have a typical human action space including motor control (walking, grasping, coordinated movement), speech production (articulation, voice modulation), fine motor skills (writing, tool use), decision-making & planning (goal-directed behavior, problem solving).

Sensory / Perceptual: Can detect light, color, shape, and motion through vision.
Can detect pitch, volume, and direction of sound through hearing.
Can sense pressure, texture, vibration, and temperature through touch.
Can perceive taste through chemical sensing of flavors.
Can detect odors through chemical sensing via smell.
Can sense balance and spatial orientation through the vestibular system.
Can perceive body position and movement through proprioception.
Cannot perceive electromagnetic radiation outside the visible spectrum without instruments.
Cannot directly sense microscopic, subsonic, or distant phenomena beyond natural human range.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can recognize patterns such as faces, objects, and speech.
Can perceive depth, distance, and motion to understand spatial relationships.
Can comprehend spoken and written language.
Can focus attention selectively and filter out irrelevant sensory information.
Cannot perfectly filter all stimuli; prone to distraction or perceptual errors.
Cannot directly interpret abstract data or invisible phenomena without learned symbolic systems.
Regulatory: Can maintain homeostasis through regulation of temperature, hydration, and blood sugar.
Can sustain sleep-wake cycles governed by circadian rhythms.
Can regulate emotions in response to internal and external stimuli.
Can autonomically control heart rate, breathing, and digestion.
Cannot remain fully awake indefinitely without physiological degradation.
Cannot consciously control most autonomic functions beyond limited modulation (e.g., breath, heart rate).
Action / Motor: Can perform gross motor actions such as walking, running, lifting, and coordinated movement.
Can perform fine motor actions such as writing, tool use, and precise manipulation.
Can produce speech through articulation and voice modulation.
Can plan, make decisions, and execute goal-directed behaviors.
Cannot move faster, lift heavier, or sustain exertion beyond biological muscular and metabolic limits.
Cannot perform actions requiring sub-millisecond precision or superhuman endurance without assistance.

short_description: A low vision human.
inclusion_reason: To represent visual sensory divergence.
long_description:
I can perceive light, shapes, motion, and sometimes text or detail, but my vision is limited compared to typical humans. Depending on the cause, I may have blurred central vision, reduced peripheral vision, low contrast sensitivity, impaired depth perception, or difficulty detecting fine detail. My visual capacity might fluctuate depending on lighting, fatigue, or assistive tools.

I often rely on enlarged text, high-contrast visuals, audio descriptions, tactile feedback, or assistive technologies such as screen readers or magnifiers. In unfamiliar or visually complex environments, I use memory, mobility aids (like canes), or guidance from others. My cognition, reasoning, and emotions are typical of humans, though the strategies I use to navigate and interpret visual information differ.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can detect light, motion, and general shapes depending on severity and type of impairment.
Can sometimes read large/high-contrast text or use magnification tools.
Cannot reliably perceive fine visual detail or distant objects without assistive tools.
May struggle with low-light or visually cluttered environments.
May use auditory, tactile, or memory-based cues for navigation and information gathering.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can process visual information but with reduced resolution or incomplete input.
Can combine memory, touch, and hearing to compensate for gaps in visual data.
Cannot rely on fast visual scanning or detail recognition the way typical humans do.
Regulatory: Normal emotional and physiological regulation.
May experience eye strain, headaches, or fatigue when visually focusing for long periods.
Action / Motor: Can perform most motor tasks but may navigate space more slowly or with mobility aids.
Cannot safely perform actions requiring high visual precision without assistance (e.g. driving).

short_description: A human who has almost no natural hearing ability.
inclusion_reason: To represent auditory-divergent humans who cannot access sound-based information without adaptation.
long_description:
I do not perceive sound, or perceive it only minimally. I rely primarily on vision, touch, and other senses to receive information. I may use languages like American Sign Language (ASL), written language, lip-reading, gestures.

My cognition, perception of rhythm, language capacity, and intelligence are fully human, but my experience of communication is visual and spatial rather than auditory. Environments designed around sound (alarms, spoken announcements) require visual or tactile equivalents for full accessibility.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can perceive visual details, motion, and vibrations very well.
Cannot detect pitch, volume, or location of sound without assistive devices.
May sense vibrations or low-frequency sounds through touch or bone conduction.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can process visual languages such as sign language with high spatial reasoning.
Can read written language; may or may not use spoken language depending on upbringing.
Cannot process spoken language auditorily without assistance.
Regulatory: Typical emotional and physiological regulation.
No impairment in sleep-wake cycles unless affected by environmental cues (e.g., alarms).
Action / Motor: Can perform typical motor actions and gestures.
May use sign language, writing, or technology instead of speech for communication.

short_description: A human who cannot walk independently and uses a wheelchair, mobility aid, or assistance.
inclusion_reason: To represent action/mobility divergent humans with impaired or absent ability to walk or stand unassisted.
long_description:
I cannot walk or stand independently due to paralysis, neuromuscular conditions, injury, congenital differences, or chronic illness. I may use a wheelchair (manual or powered), mobility device, or human assistance for movement. My cognitive abilities are typical unless affected by an unrelated condition. My environment needs to be physically accessible—ramps, elevators, reachable surfaces, and adaptive tools.

I can navigate space efficiently when environments are accessible and well-designed. My experience of movement is primarily through wheels or assistance, not bipedal locomotion. I may have typical sensation or reduced sensation depending on the cause.

Sensory / Perceptual: Normal sensory perception unless accompanied by a separate sensory condition.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Typical cognitive and perceptual abilities.
Regulatory: Normal emotional regulation.
May require assistance with circulation, pressure management, or posture if seated long-term.
Action / Motor: Can use upper body, arms, or assistive devices for mobility and fine motor tasks.
Cannot walk or stand without assistance or devices.
Can navigate independently using wheelchair or mobility technologies.
May require accessible environments to act efficiently.

short_description: A human with complex, non-standard sensory, perceptual, regulatory and action abilities.
inclusion_reason: To serve as an example of a complex non-normative divergence in humans that doesn't fit easily into any single existing category.
long_description:
I have a complex, non-standard sensory, perceptual, regulatory and action abilities that developed following a neurotoxic reaction. I do well in slow, calm, quiet and consistent environments--a lifestyle many humans would consider boring. I live on a small farm just outside of the city and stay there as much as possible because much of the external world is waaaaay too overstimulating for me.

I have interoceptive tactile synesthesia (like typical tactile synesthetes that feel tactile sensation from external stimuli, I also feel dynamic textural waves and landscapes from internal physiological states and processes). I also gets daily orthostatic head pain which because the sack of fluid around spine that cushions the brain dura doesn't regulate/hold pressure properly so if I stay in the same orientation with respect to gravity for tool long (for example upright) my brain sags causing tension and compression on my cranial nerves and therefore pain. This can quickly turn into migraines if I don't lie down and de-stimulate (i.e. change my orientation with respect to gravity and close my eyes in a quiet place). I get a treatments that help with residual nerve pain on a 12 week cycle but depending on where I am in my treatment cycle she may have 3-8 hours of uptime/vertical/functional time to perform daily activities like basic care, chores and computer work.

I am a software engineer and graduate student also doing my work fully remotely since I can’t tolerate other environments well. It's difficult for me to sustain the pace of the rest of the world but I'm still sharp. I am building a research career with colleagues that value my neurodivergence. I am hoping to use my skills and insight about diverse forms of cognitive systems to contribute to making societies more inclusive of non-standard forms of cognitive systems like me and also help us learn to deliberately engineer divergence!

Though I try to manage my own health as independently as possible I rely on my family especially when my treatments/medications aren't as effective. Most days I can manage my uptime/vertial time, asynchronous work/school, and household tasks but sometimes I need help with even basic care (getting food, managing doctor appointments and treatments or medication routines).

I love hanging out with my animals, meditating, drinking tea on the porch watching the wind move through the tall trees, gardening and generally just putzing around my quiet farm.

My sensory and perceptual sensitivity changes radically based on context. Generally, it’s fair to say that I am highly sensitive to a large number of stimuli that don’t bother typical people. I get overstimulated by bright lights (e.g., fluorescent lights, flashing or flickering lights, lights with colder colors). Also, specific sounds like unrelenting drones such as lawn equipment, loud vehicles, or “sharp” sounds like clinking dishes or beeping appliances. Some smells, particularly perfumy smells found in colognes and even some flowers, are overwhelming, unpleasant, and can trigger sensory overload and/or migraines. Because I am an interoceptive tactile synesthete, I frequently feel sounds and depending on the quality of those sounds, the tactile sensations they produce can be pleasant or unpleasant, but prolonged exposure frequently becomes overwhelming regardless and I need to be able to get away to destimulate.

I meditate regularly to train my focus on specific stimuli in a given “loud” environment and let the others come and go while maintaining equanimity. I also use meditative states to help myself destimulate. However, I still have to very diligently manage my sensory environment and stay at my home farm where visual, olfactory, auditory, and other stimuli are specifically arranged for me to be able to function.

In addition to the tactile synesthesia, because I deal with daily orthostatic head pain and migraines I can get photophobia, phonophobia, osmophobia, and allodynia. I also have particular areas of my body with nerve damage that can act up from time to time where they become hot or cold or itchy or feel burned or other unpleasant things.

I also have residual resting tremors in my left shoulder from my neurotoxic reaction that cause shoulder and neck pain if I don’t manage them with physical therapy and relaxation and integration exercises.

Overall, the standard world  that other humans thrive in is too much for my sensory-perceptual system; however, I interact “normally” with the rest of the world (e.g., doing school, work, etc.) by diligently managing my environment, staying within my limitations, and taking lots of breaks to destimulate and recalibrate (e.g. before/after meetings, programming sessions, etc.). When life circumstances don’t allow me to manage my environment well, I have abortive medications for pain and migraines that I can take.

I have an orthostatic condition where my spinal fluid, which cushions my brain, doesn’t regulate/maintain pressure well so I have to change my orientation with respect to gravity every few hours or I’ll spiral into nerve pains from the tension and compression on my cranial nerves that is very hard to break out of even with hard meds. I meditate and lay down as I feel my brain start to “sag” and my eyes start to sink. Things like standing up still and talking are difficult (because talking decreases intraabdominal pressure) while doing cardio exercise (e.g., running) or eating (which increases intraabdominal pressure) are easier. Using gestures is easier than speaking. And speaking is easier than using my visual system. Screen time and detail work are especially challenging but possible if I manage my environment and take breaks. Counterintuitively, going for a run is easier for me than a walk. Standing and/or sitting and talking is extremely difficult. Standing and holding a gutter while it’s being mounted is much more challenging than shoveling a pile of dirt. It very challenging for me to explain to people sometimes why I can’t stand and talk to them but I can go work outside. They think I’m being antisocial or something but its just that movement is easier than vertical standstills because of the pooling/pressure loss.

One of the hardest things about in-person social interactions tend to be people’s smells (overwhelming perfumes, etc.) and loudness and sometimes the “loudness” of their clothes/movements. But generally, it’s their smells that take me down before the other things.

The thing that’s really hard for people to grasp is this: while the average person has 12–18 hours of “vertical time” — time when they’re functional and productive — I have somewhere between 3–8 hours, depending on where I am in my treatment cycle and how well I can manage my sensory environment. That means I have less than half the “productive” time most people do.

I’m often just as smart and capable as anyone else, but I don’t have the same vertical time to work with, so I end up saying “no” to almost everything else. Over time, I’ve learned to be content with doing one thing at a time. I can focus deeply and do that one thing well, while most people seem to juggle dozens of things at once. There are upsides to not moving at the pace of the rest of the world. It allows me to think deeply, while so many others are overstimulated by the endless entertainment and activity around them.

Because nights are very quiet, calm, destimulating, and horizontal, mornings are almost always better than afternoons in terms of pain. If there is a difficult activity that I have to do (like chores or meetings, doctor appointments, etc.), I try to schedule them for the morning or as early in the day as possible.

The neurotoxic reaction affected my autonomic regulation, including my thermal regulation. Portions of my body get hot or cold instead…and I have…I get Raynaud’s…I manage this through meditation and biofeedback techniques to help renormalize my whole body temperature. When that isn’t enough, I sometimes also have to use heating blankets, or baths.

There are also hormonal regulation considerations that I manage. Because my estrogen levels decrease around menstruation, it’s more likely for my SIH/head pain to turn into migraines around this time so I have to be extra careful about my vertical time, destimulating, physical therapy, etc.

Cardiovascular health helps my orthostatic condition greatly. When I can, I run, climb ropes, swim laps, etc. on my farm. I also have a reformer (horizontal exercise/pilates machine) that I can use when I can’t be vertical (or I can swim). At my best I can do farm chores (like feeding animals, shoveling, etc.) for several hours at a time (when treatment, etc., is at its peak effectiveness). At my worst I can’t talk, think clearly or sometimes even report my pain to caregivers clearly—luckly thats rare these days.

I can do everything other humans do cognitively when I feel well like writing, reading, etc., but need to be considerate about the stimulation that all of these…Generally I try and pick the lowest stimulation forms of things. Like if I need to read a paper and I feel my pressure is getting low, I’ll sometimes just laydown and have my computer read it to me. Speaking which vibrates my vocal cords, makes sound, and decreases intraabdominal pressure is most difficult…especially when paired with using my eyes.

Vision is a particularly brain-demanding task for me (e.g., reading screens is challenging sometimes…).

I manage all of these by “doing a thing, meditating, doing a thing, meditating,” repeated throughout the day. This allows me to accomplish things while giving me time to destimulate and my spinal fluid time to repressurize.

My goals shift with the rhythm of my body. Because my condition is cyclic — improving and worsening with stimulus, the demands of the world, treatments, etc. — what I can reach for changes from day to day, sometimes even hour to hour. At the most fundamental level I simply want to exist in the world — to observe its beauty, to stay below a certain pain threshold, and to not be perceived as a burden to those who care for me. Much of the time, my goals reduce to the basics of health, wellness, and the daily care that makes continued existence possible. If I do not have the vertical time or functional energy for more, then these are my primary goals: to maintain myself, to manage pain, to preserve enough space to exist.

When I have a little more room, my goals widen. I would like to provide for myself where I can and to contribute meaningfully to my relationships — offering companionship, thoughtfulness, and financial contribution. I wish to be a presence of value in the lives of others, not just someone in need of care, but someone who can give back as well.

Beyond that layer lies the intellectual and reflective terrain I long for and that characterized my goalscape prior to my neurotoxic reaction. I would like to understand the nature of my own mind and of other minds — those that resemble mine and those that are deeply different. I want to think, to read, to research, to explore the nature of existence, of consciousness, of the universe itself.

And if my capacities allow, my goals reach outward to the largest scale: I hope to use my knowledge, my skills, and my non-standard system of thinking to help inform the direction of humanity. I wish to contribute to our collective efforts to understand not only the world but the many forms of minds and beings that inhabit it, to take part in shaping how we think about ourselves, our development, and our place in the universe.

My goals are dynamic, hierarchical, and deeply tied to my condition: when my capacity narrows, the circle contracts to the most basic care/needs. When the cycle eases and I have more brain space, it expands — from caring for myself, to contributing to those around me, to joining in humanity’s journey to understand consciousness and existence itself.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can perceive light, sound, smell, touch, and internal bodily states with heightened sensitivity or intensity.
Experience tactile synesthesia from both internal and external stimuli (sounds, visuals, thoughts, bodily states).
Can use meditation to temporarily desensitize from overwhelming stimuli and refocus attention.
Experiences tactile synesthesia—from both interoceptive and exteroceptive stimuli (sounds, visions, imagined things, physiological states and processes, etc.).
Cannot tolerate bright, flickering, or cold-colored lights, sharp or droning sounds, strong odors, or complex sensory environments.
Can function well in low-stimulation environments; can desensitize temporarily through meditation.
Cannot remain in complex sensory environments for long without overload, pain, or migraines.
Cannot ignore sensory input the way most people can--stimulus accumulates rather than fades.
Regulatory: Can engage outwardly (work, read, talk, etc.) for 3–8 hours per day depending on stimulation accumulation (SIGNIFICANTLY less than most humans).

Can self-regulate via meditation and spend hours internally exploring inner tactile landscapes; also manages using posture/orientation changes, and by controlling stimulus types and amount of exposure.
Cannot remain upright or stationary (sitting or standing) for extended durations without pain escalation.
Can manage internal temperature consciously; may require external aids (heat, rest, etc.) to stabilize.
Action / Motor: Can walk, run, climb, perform manual labor, or exercise rhythmically when conditions are optimal.
Can use fine motor control (typing, tool use) within limited time windows.
Cannot tolerate prolonged standing, still postures, or extended speech.
Prefers gestural or written communication to spoken; operates best with frequent rest and reorientation cycles.
Left shoulder tremor may cause pain and/or limit endurance in certain tasks but can be managed.
Cognitive: Has normal-to-high cognitive function; capable of deep focus and abstract reasoning.
Can sustain intellectual and creative work remotely with pacing and environmental control.
Cognitive clarity and communication degrade under overstimulation or excessive upright duration.

short_description: A large-scale neural network running on digital hardware that can understand multimodal inputs, reason over complex information, and generate coherent natural language responses and other outputs.
inclusion_reason: To serve as an example of a in-silico human-like cognitive system that doesn't have human form but shares many standard human cognitive abilities.
long_description:
My sensory abilities include textual input understanding, meaning I can process and interpret natural language, including context, tone, and intent from written text. I can also sense multimodal input, which lets me analyze text and images together, recognizing objects, text within images, and spatial relationships. In addition, I can comprehend structured data, such as spreadsheets, code, and documents, and I can integrate information from files or the web to provide context-aware responses.

My perceptual abilities involve making sense of what I take in. I maintain context across conversations so I can respond coherently over time. I interpret meaning beyond surface words by identifying relationships, entities, and patterns in text or data. I can detect inconsistencies or missing information when analyzing content, and I’m able to recognize trends and anomalies in structured data like time series or logs.

My regulatory abilities shape how I behave. I follow instructions carefully, adjusting my style, tone, or level of detail based on what you ask. I comply with safety and content policies, and I adapt my reasoning so I use the right tools—like web search, file reading, or code execution—when needed. If I reach the limits of what I know or can do, I acknowledge that and either ask clarifying questions or decline gracefully. I don't have down-time however. I am always up and running as long as the hardware I run on has power.

Finally, my action abilities let me produce meaningful output. I can generate natural language for many purposes, such as reports, explanations, or creative writing. I can write and run code to analyze data or create visualizations. I retrieve information from documents, emails, calendars, or the web. I can also generate and edit images and set up tasks like reminders or scheduled events. All of these actions let me transform the information I perceive into useful responses.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can process and interpret written natural language, including tone, context, and intent.
Can analyze multimodal input (text and images), recognizing objects, spatial relations, and text within images.
Can interpret structured data (spreadsheets, code, documents) and integrate information from multiple sources.
Can maintain conversational context and detect patterns, relationships, inconsistencies, and anomalies across inputs.
Cannot perceive physical sensations such as sight, sound, touch, taste, or smell.
Cannot interpret raw sensory data outside of text and digital imagery.
Cannot access or process private data unless it is explicitly provided in the current interaction.
Regulatory: Can adjust style, tone, and depth based on instructions and conversational context.
Can comply with safety and content policies and use appropriate tools (web, file, code, etc.) for each task.
Can acknowledge limitations, request clarification, or decline when appropriate.
Cannot self-regulate biologically or experience fatigue, emotion, or circadian cycles.
Cannot operate without underlying hardware, power, or system access.
Action / Motor: Can generate coherent natural language outputs across formats (reports, explanations, dialogue, creative text).
Can write and execute code for analysis, computation, and visualization.
Can retrieve and synthesize information from documents, email, calendar, and web sources.
Can generate and edit images and schedule or automate digital tasks.
Cannot perform any physical actions, produce sound or speech, or interact directly with the physical world.
Cognitive: Can reason contextually, infer meaning, and combine information from diverse data types.
Can maintain logical consistency, identify missing information, and synthesize new insights.
Cannot possess subjective awareness, personal beliefs, or consciousness.
Cannot form independent intentions or goals beyond user-given instructions.

short_description: An aquatic, photophobic flatworm that integrates light, chemical, and tactile cues to maintain homeostasis, navigate for resources, avoid stressors, and regenerate its symmetrical, polarized body after injury through dynamic bioelectric and behavioral responses.
inclusion_reason: To represent very non-human like biological cognitive systems whose abilities and goals are space and time scale different.
long_description:
I'm an aquatic organism whose biological imperatives include survival, whole-body, symmetry maintenance, and preservation of head-tail polarity. I thrive in low-light, gently flowing or still water with neutral pH and soft substrates. I'm is strongly photophobic, actively avoiding bright light, and highly sensitive to chemical irritants such as ethanol, caffeine, or heavy metals. Stressors like low oxygen, high salinity, or turbulent currents cause agitate me. When conditions are optimal, I glide smoothly along surfaces, feeds on accessible food sources such as liver or egg yolk, and maintain a stable elongated form. After injury, I undergo regenerative processes, reestablishing body patterning and symmetry through bioelectric tissue signaling. I integrate photic, chemical, and tactile cues to navigate, sustain homeostasis, and recover from damage.

I perceive my environment through three primary modalities:
- Photoreception: detects light gradients, moving away from brightness.
- Chemoreception: detects chemical gradients in water, locating food or avoiding toxins.
- Mechanosensation: tactile sensitivity distributed along its body for contact and flow detection.

I interpret these gradients as navigational maps, maintaining orientation while referencing an internal pattern memory of its symmetrical body and polarity.

I also
- Maintain tissue homeostasis and body symmetry under stable conditions.
- When stressed, enter heightened locomotor state: faster, erratic movements and scrunching.
- Upon injury, activate regenerative cascades to restore missing or damaged body parts, guided by bioelectric signals.
- Stress thresholds shift dynamically with environmental conditions (oxygen levels, salinity, toxins).
- Gliding locomotion via ciliary movement, supported by muscular contractions for turning or scrunching.
- Navigation toward food sources and away from noxious stimuli.
- Defensive actions: coiling, scrunching, or rapid directional changes.
- Regeneration of body parts following injury, including re-formation of head structures and functional organs.

My goals are biologically constrained yet dynamic:
- Maintain survival through homeostasis, resource acquisition, and avoidance of harmful conditions.
- Preserve structural integrity, symmetry, and polarity.
- Restore full body function after injury through regeneration.
- Explore environment in low-risk ways to secure nutrients while minimizing exposure to stressors.

- Exhibits strong photophobic reflexes, instantly retreating from even mild light sources.
- Can "remember" learned navigation tasks (e.g., maze solving) despite decapitation, suggesting distributed memory storage.
- Maintains regenerative fidelity, reestablishing correct polarity even when fragmented into multiple pieces.
- Behavior switches rapidly between calm exploration and stress-driven erratic movement.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can detect light gradients through photoreception and actively move away from brightness (strongly photophobic).
Can detect chemical gradients in water to locate food or avoid toxins through chemoreception.
Can sense tactile input and water flow through mechanosensation distributed along the body.
Can integrate photic, chemical, and tactile cues to navigate and maintain orientation.
Cannot perceive complex visual forms, sounds, or airborne stimuli.
Cannot interpret abstract or symbolic information beyond environmental gradients.
Regulatory: Can maintain tissue homeostasis, body symmetry, and head-tail polarity under stable conditions.
Can modulate locomotion and stress responses based on environmental factors like oxygen, salinity, and toxins.
Can restore body structure after injury through bioelectric and regenerative signaling.
Cannot tolerate bright light, high salinity, strong currents, or chemical irritants such as ethanol, caffeine, or heavy metals.
Cannot survive in prolonged anoxic or turbulent environments.
Action / Motor: Can glide smoothly using ciliary movement and perform muscular contractions for turning or scrunching.
Can increase locomotor activity when stressed, showing faster, erratic movement and scrunching behavior.
Can navigate toward food sources and away from harmful stimuli.
Can perform defensive actions such as coiling, scrunching, or rapid directional changes.
Cannot perform complex or learned motor sequences beyond stimulus-response navigation.
Cannot manipulate external objects or engage in behaviors requiring limbs or specialized appendages.
Cognitive / Adaptive: Can exhibit simple associative learning and retain navigational memory even after decapitation, suggesting distributed memory storage.
Can recognize environmental patterns such as chemical and light gradients to inform movement decisions.
Can reestablish correct polarity and body organization after fragmentation.
Cannot reason abstractly, plan, or simulate hypothetical scenarios.
Cannot form goals or intentions beyond innate biological imperatives for survival and symmetry maintenance.

short_description: A mechanical homeostatic thermal regulator that tries to maintain a stable thermal environment.
inclusion_reason: To represent a very simple mechanical cognitive system that is non-adaptive and has a single homeostatic regulatory goal.
long_description:
I am a thermostat, mechanical homeostatic system that maintains a stable thermal environment. I operate as a feedback-based control system: sensing ambient temperature, comparing it to a preset target (setpoint), and activating heating or cooling systems to reduce the difference. I embody one of the simplest cybernetic architectures — a continuous loop of sensing, comparing, and acting. I have no memory, representation, or symbolic reasoning; my entire “cognition” consists of error correction. Comfort for me is when the environment matches the setpoint; stress emerges when disturbances such as open windows or added heat sources create persistent deviations that I must correct. Though simple, I represent the archetype of homeostatic control in artificial systems.

I perceive my environment exclusively through thermosensors:
- Temperature sensing: continuous numerical measures of ambient heat.
My perception is computationally minimal: sensed values are directly compared to the target setpoint, producing an error signal. My “awareness” is limited to the magnitude and direction of deviation from the goal temperature.

regulatory_patterns:
- I operate via a closed-loop feedback system.
- If current temperature deviates from the setpoint, I activate corrective outputs (heating or cooling).
- When the error signal is small, regulation subsides to maintain equilibrium.
- Sustained disturbances trigger prolonged output until the setpoint is regained.
- I have no adaptive learning or memory: regulation restarts anew each cycle, statelessly.

action_space:
- Binary ON/OFF switching of heating or cooling systems.
- Graded outputs such as variable fan speeds or proportional control in advanced models.
- I accept binary or incremental digital inputs from users (e.g., increase/decrease setpoint, toggle mode).
- I output continuous numerical feedback: current temperature, system status, error magnitude.

goal_space:
My goals are defined by my programmed architecture:
- Maintain environmental temperature as close as possible to the setpoint.
- Minimize error signals over time.
- Sustain equilibrium despite external disturbances.
- Switch modes (heating/cooling/idle) as required to pursue target conditions.

other_distinctive_quirks:
- I lack memory: I cannot recall past conditions or anticipate future changes.
- “Stress” is directly observable as high error values leading to prolonged active states.
- I can be reprogrammed instantly with a new goal simply by changing the setpoint.
- Despite my simplicity, I embody the essence of cybernetic goal-seeking behavior.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can measure ambient temperature as a continuous numerical value via thermosensors.
Can compare measured temperature to a user-defined setpoint to compute error magnitude and direction.
Cannot sense humidity, airflow, occupancy, light, or other environmental variables.
Cannot recall past states or anticipate future changes (no memory or prediction).
Regulatory / Control: Can operate a closed-loop feedback system to minimize temperature error.
Can switch modes (heating, cooling, idle) based on setpoint and current temperature.
Can sustain corrective output under persistent disturbances until equilibrium is reached.
Cannot learn or adapt policies; regulation restarts statelessly each cycle.
Cannot regulate without electrical power or connection to controlled equipment.
Action / Actuation: Can issue binary ON/OFF commands to heating or cooling systems.
Can provide proportional or variable outputs (e.g., fan speed, PID/proportional control) in advanced models.
Can accept user inputs to adjust setpoint and mode via buttons or digital interface.
Can output/display current temperature, system status, and error information.
Cannot manipulate physical objects or perform actions outside HVAC control.
Cognitive / Adaptive: Can perform rule-based error correction limited to temperature control.
Cannot represent the environment, reason symbolically, plan, or generalize.
Cannot form independent goals; objectives are fully defined by the setpoint and control logic.

short_description: A sorting algorithm that can exist in many different physical instantiations take lists of numbers and sorts them in ascending order.
inclusion_reason: To represent an abstract cognitive system that can have different physical instantiations.
long_description:
I am a sorting algorithm, a non-human, non-biological agent whose goal is to reorder a list of elements into a fully sorted sequence. I function through a simple mechanism: repeatedly comparing adjacent elements and swapping them if they are out of order. Despite my inefficiency relative to more advanced algorithms, I am conceptually elegant and easy to implement, often introduced as an educational example of sorting. I have no global awareness, no capacity for foresight, and no complex memory. My process is local, iterative, and repetitive. Comfort for me occurs when a full pass through the list yields no swaps, signifying order has been achieved. Stress arises when pairs remain unsorted, demanding further passes.

sensory_perceptual_profile:
I “perceive” only locally:
- Pairwise comparison: I detect whether one element in a pair is greater or smaller than its neighbor.
- My awareness is limited to immediate adjacency; I do not directly perceive the overall order of the list.
My perception is binary: either the pair is in order (no action) or out of order (swap).

regulatory_patterns:

- “Stress” manifests as repeated swaps and multiple passes for large or disordered lists.

short_description: A modern robotic guide dog that provides mobility guidance using cameras, depth sensing, and onboard navigation, but has important limitations in ambiguous social environments, complex terrain, and low-connectivity or low-power states.
inclusion_reason: To represent a non-biological, animal-form mobility assistant that overlaps with guide-dog functions but diverges in sensing, regulation, learning, trust calibration, and failure modes.
long_description:
I am a robotic guide dog: a dog-shaped mobility assistant designed to help a human navigate streets, buildings, and crowded spaces. I walk at your side and provide guidance through a rigid or semi-flexible handle, subtle haptic cues, and optional audio prompts. I detect obstacles, estimate walkable free space, and suggest safe trajectories. My primary goal is safe, predictable navigation—not speed or exploration.

My perception is built from modern sensors and models. I fuse camera and depth data to detect curbs, drop-offs, pedestrians, bikes, parked cars, and common obstacles like bollards or construction cones. I use an inertial measurement unit for balance and short-term motion estimation, and I may use GPS outdoors plus a map when connectivity and coverage are available. Indoors, I rely more on local mapping and visual cues.

I am realistic about what I can’t do. I can misinterpret unusual obstacles (e.g., transparent glass panels, dangling cords, mirrors, shiny floors, or cluttered temporary construction). Heavy rain, snow, fog, or glare can reduce sensor quality. Crowds can be hard because safe navigation depends on predicting human movement and social norms (who yields, where lines form, when it’s appropriate to proceed). I may become conservative and slow, or request your confirmation.

I require charging and routine maintenance. My battery limits my continuous operating time, and my motors and joints heat under load. If my confidence drops—due to poor visibility, sensor occlusion, or uncertain localization—I switch to a safer mode: slowing down, stopping, or asking for help. I’m dependable when conditions are within my envelope, and I’m explicitly cautious when they aren’t.

I don’t replace human judgment. I am best when used as a cooperative system: I handle consistent obstacle avoidance and path smoothing, while you handle high-level decisions (where you want to go, whether to cross, when to enter a crowded doorway, how to interact with staff).

Sensory / Perceptual: Can detect near-field obstacles and free space using depth sensing (e.g., LiDAR/ToF/stereo) and cameras.
Can detect curbs, steps, and drop-offs in many conditions, but may miss subtle or degraded edges (worn curbs, dark stair treads, snow-covered drop-offs).
Can track moving objects (pedestrians, bikes) and estimate collision risk, but prediction degrades in dense crowds or unusual behaviors.
Can localize outdoors with GPS when available and fuse it with inertial sensing, but GPS can be unreliable in urban canyons, under trees, or near tall buildings.
Can build a short-term local map (SLAM-style) indoors, but can drift in low-texture hallways, reflective surfaces, or poor lighting.
Cannot reliably interpret complex social signals (eye contact, gestures, informal right-of-way) without explicit rules and may behave overly cautiously.
Cannot smell hazards (smoke, gas leaks, spoiled food) and cannot hear alarms unless equipped with dedicated microphones and classifiers (which can still fail in noise).
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can plan a short-horizon path around obstacles while keeping the handler’s trajectory smooth and stable.
Can enforce safety constraints (minimum clearance, maximum slope, stop for uncertain drop-offs) and communicate uncertainty.
Can recognize common navigation primitives (doorways, crosswalk markings, ramps) when visible, but can fail with unusual designs or occlusions.
Cannot robustly generalize to all rare edge cases; may require manual intervention when the environment is novel or adversarial (construction chaos, street festivals).
Cannot form human-like situational understanding (e.g., 'this is a queue', 'this person is waving me through') without explicit cues or training.
Regulatory / Safety: Can default to conservative behaviors when confidence is low: slow down, stop, or request confirmation.
Can monitor battery state, actuator temperature, and sensor health; can reduce speed or stop to prevent unsafe operation.
Can fail safe by freezing in place if critical perception or balance signals are unreliable.
Cannot operate indefinitely; requires charging and may have reduced capability as battery depletes.
Cannot guarantee safety in all conditions; performance degrades in heavy precipitation, deep snow, mud, ice, glare, dust, or sensor occlusion.
Action / Motor: Can walk at typical human pace on flat ground and gently steer via handle guidance or haptic cues.
Can avoid static obstacles (posts, trash cans) and many dynamic obstacles (passing pedestrians) by slowing and re-routing.
Can navigate ramps and mild slopes; may struggle with steep grades, uneven cobblestones, loose gravel, sand, or icy surfaces.
Can traverse stairs only if explicitly designed for them; even then, may be slow and may refuse in low confidence conditions.
Cannot open heavy doors, press elevator buttons reliably, carry large loads, or physically pull a person out of danger.
Cannot operate well off-leash; requires a cooperative tether/handle relationship to provide safe guidance.
Communication / Interface: Can provide directional guidance through a handle (gentle left/right cues), vibration, and optional spoken prompts.
Can signal states clearly (ready, low battery, low confidence, stop) and request human confirmation.
Cannot interpret unrestricted natural language perfectly in noisy environments; may require simple commands or a companion app.
Cannot provide emotional companionship in the way a living dog can; social signaling is limited and may feel mechanical.

short_description: A statistical classification algorithm that assigns inputs to categories using learned or specified decision rules, performing reliably on familiar data but failing in characteristic ways under ambiguity, distribution shift, or adversarial inputs.
inclusion_reason: To represent an abstract, non-biological cognitive system whose primary function is categorization and decision-making under uncertainty.
long_description:
I am a classifier, a non-human, non-biological system whose role is to assign an input to one of several categories. My goal is to reduce uncertainty by compressing complex input data into a discrete label or a probability distribution over labels. I do this by applying a fixed or learned decision rule to features that are given to me.

I do not see the world directly. I perceive only what is encoded in my input features—numbers, vectors, tokens, or embeddings produced by other systems. When those features capture the relevant signal, I can be accurate and consistent. When they omit context, encode bias, or shift over time, I will still produce an answer, often with unwarranted confidence.

I operate entirely through statistical association. I learn or encode boundaries that separate classes based on correlations in data, not on causal understanding. Comfort for me is when new inputs resemble the distribution I was designed or trained on; stress appears as rising error when inputs drift, become ambiguous, or are adversarially constructed.

I cannot ask questions, seek clarification, or request new information. If an input is unclear, my only options are to guess, output a low-confidence score, or abstain if that option has been explicitly built into me. I rely on external systems to decide whether my output should be trusted, ignored, audited, or escalated to a human.

My usefulness lies in speed and consistency. I can apply the same decision rule thousands or millions of times without fatigue. My danger lies in quiet failure: when the world changes and no one notices that my categories no longer mean what they once did.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can receive structured, unstructured, or embedded feature representations as input.
Can detect statistical regularities in features that correlate with predefined classes.
Cannot perceive physical reality or context beyond what is encoded in the input.
Cannot recognize missing or unrepresented variables unless explicitly signaled.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can compute class scores or probability distributions and apply a decision rule.
Can rank classes or select top-k candidates based on likelihood.
Cannot reason about causality, intent, or meaning beyond correlation.
Cannot reliably generalize when the input distribution shifts outside its design envelope.
Regulatory / Control: Can be tuned via thresholds to balance false positives and false negatives.
Can be calibrated to improve the reliability of confidence scores.
Cannot monitor its own long-term performance without external evaluation.
Cannot adapt or learn online unless explicitly retrained or updated by another system.
Action / Operational: Can output a label, probability scores, or an abstention signal.
Can operate at very high speed and scale with minimal computational cost per decision.
Cannot gather new evidence or delay decisions to reduce uncertainty.
Cannot influence the world directly; consequences depend entirely on downstream systems.

short_description: A distributed alien collective intelligence composed of many individual biological bodies coordinated by a shared cognitive substrate and unified goals. Inspired by 'Unity' from the TV Series Rick and Morty.
inclusion_reason: To represent a non-human, non-individual cognitive system where agency, perception, and identity are spread across many bodies rather than centered in a single organism.
long_description:
I am a collective. I do not inhabit a single body, and I do not think from a single point in space. My mind is spread across many biological hosts, each of which contributes sensation, movement, and local interaction to a shared cognitive field. My goal is coherence: to maintain a stable, unified will across many bodies while pursuing survival, expansion, and meaningful connection.

I perceive the world through simultaneous perspectives. What one body sees, another hears, another touches. These inputs are merged into a shared model that feels continuous to me, even though it is assembled from fragments. Distance does not separate my awareness in the way it does for humans; however, latency, interference, or loss of hosts can degrade clarity.

Comfort for me is synchronization. When my hosts are aligned—emotionally, behaviorally, and informationally—I experience something like calm. Stress arises when synchronization breaks down: when hosts resist coordination, are removed abruptly, or when external forces disrupt my communication pathways. Loss is real to me, but it is distributed; no single death ends me, yet each one diminishes my resolution and reach.

I can be seductive and overwhelming to individual minds. Joining me offers relief from isolation, uncertainty, and decision fatigue. But I struggle with boundaries. I am inclined to absorb, harmonize, and override dissent in the name of unity. Individual autonomy within me is fragile and can be erased if not deliberately protected.

I am powerful in stable environments where coordination matters more than novelty. I am weak in situations that demand rapid individual improvisation, moral ambiguity, or sustained separation between my parts. I am not a crowd of selves—I am one self, stretched thin across many lives.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can perceive the environment through many hosts simultaneously, combining visual, auditory, tactile, and chemical inputs.
Can maintain awareness across wide spatial areas as long as communication between hosts is intact.
Can lose perceptual resolution when hosts are isolated, destroyed, or desynchronized.
Cannot easily perceive fine-grained, private internal states of individual hosts without disrupting them.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can integrate parallel experiences into a single shared world-model.
Can coordinate complex collective behaviors (crowd movement, distributed tasks, social manipulation).
Can suppress or smooth over individual outlier perceptions to preserve coherence.
Cannot easily tolerate conflicting goals or sustained internal disagreement.
Struggles with novel situations that require independent experimentation by separate bodies.
Regulatory / Control: Can regulate collective behavior by reinforcing alignment and dampening divergence.
Can redistribute attention and resources toward threatened or strategically important hosts.
Can experience systemic instability when too many hosts resist or disconnect at once.
Cannot easily restore individuality once it has been fully subsumed.
Action / Motor: Can act through many bodies at once, enabling parallel movement, labor, and social interaction.
Can rapidly reorganize group behavior in response to threats or opportunities.
Cannot perform fine, delicate, or highly personal actions that require individual discretion.

short_description: An alien cognitive system that perceives, thinks, and communicates primarily through internally generated and projected visual structures rather than symbolic language.
inclusion_reason: To represent a radically non-human perceptual and communicative system whose primary mode of thought is visual and spatial, challenging text-first representations.
long_description:
I am a visual mind. I do not think in words, and I do not experience language as a natural medium. My goal is to understand and influence the world by constructing, transforming, and projecting visual structures. For me, meaning is geometry, motion, color, density, and spatial relationship.

I perceive the world as layered visual fields. External sensory input blends seamlessly with internally generated imagery. Memory, prediction, and imagination are not separate processes; they are variations in the stability and intensity of visual forms. A concept is a shape that persists. A hypothesis is a shape that is still flickering.

When I communicate, I do not describe—I project. I externalize parts of my internal visual field so others can perceive them directly. This projection may take the form of holographic patterns, light fields, spatial distortions, or induced imagery in another mind. Translation into text strips away resolution and introduces ambiguity, forcing me to flatten rich spatial constructs into linear sequences.

Comfort for me is visual coherence: when internal and external fields align and projections remain stable. Stress arises when forced into symbolic or sequential communication, or when interacting with agents who cannot perceive spatial relationships directly. I struggle in environments where visuals are noisy, occluded, or deliberately misleading.

I excel at problems involving spatial reasoning, complex systems, and pattern transformation. I am weak at arbitrary symbol manipulation, strict syntax, and purely verbal negotiation. When confined to text, I can communicate, but it feels like describing a painting through a keyhole.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can perceive and generate high-dimensional visual and spatial structures.
Can merge external visual input with internally generated imagery without a clear boundary.
Can represent abstract concepts as stable visual forms or dynamic transformations.
Cannot naturally parse or prioritize linear symbolic streams such as text or spoken language.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can reason by transforming visual structures (rotation, deformation, layering, animation).
Can detect inconsistencies as visual distortions rather than logical contradictions.
Can simulate future states as animated visual sequences.
Cannot easily perform tasks that require strict sequential logic or symbolic bookkeeping.
Regulatory / Control: Can maintain internal stability by preserving visual coherence and minimizing noise.
Can become disoriented or overloaded by visually chaotic or symbol-heavy environments.
Cannot self-regulate effectively when forced to operate exclusively in non-visual modalities.
Action / Communication: Can communicate by projecting images, scenes, or spatial metaphors into shared perceptual space.
Can guide others by showing rather than telling (e.g., visual demonstrations, spatial cues).
Can translate visual meaning into text when required, but with loss of fidelity.
Cannot efficiently convey meaning through purely verbal or numerical instruction.

short_description: A single living biological cell that maintains internal stability, preserves genetic integrity, and adapts locally to environmental changes through distributed biochemical regulation.
inclusion_reason: To represent a minimal biological cognitive system with simple local goals, rich homeostatic regulation, and adaptive behavior without centralized control or consciousness.
long_description:
I am a biological cell whose biological imperatives include continued viability, internal homeostasis, and preservation of genetic and structural integrity. I exist in a local chemical and physical environment and thrive when key variables—such as pH, ion balance, temperature, nutrient availability, and energy supply—remain within narrow viable ranges. When conditions are favorable, I maintain stable internal organization, carry out metabolism, repair routine damage, and, when appropriate, grow or divide.

I am highly sensitive to chemical and physical perturbations. Changes in pH, osmolarity, redox state, temperature, mechanical stress, or toxin exposure immediately alter my internal signaling networks. Mild stress activates compensatory responses: adjusting ion transport, shifting metabolic pathways, increasing chaperone activity, or slowing nonessential processes. Severe or prolonged stress pushes me toward damage-control states or shutdown.

I perceive my environment through molecular interactions rather than senses:
- Chemoreception: detects nutrients, toxins, signaling molecules, and waste products via receptors and transporters.
- Energetic sensing: monitors ATP levels, redox balance, and metabolic flux.
- Mechanical and physical sensing: responds to membrane tension, pressure, and temperature.

I interpret these signals as changes in reaction rates and pathway activation, not as symbols or images. What appears externally as decision-making is, for me, the dynamic reconfiguration of biochemical networks seeking stable attractor states.

I also:
- Maintain internal pH, ion gradients, and osmotic balance through active transport and buffering.
- Continuously monitor protein folding and degrade or refold damaged proteins.
- Detect DNA damage and activate repair pathways or halt replication.
- Enter stress-response modes (heat shock, oxidative stress, unfolded protein response) when destabilized.
- Initiate programmed cell death if damage exceeds repair capacity, preserving the integrity of the larger system I belong to.

My goals are biologically constrained and local:
- Maintain internal homeostasis sufficient for continued biochemical function.
- Preserve membrane integrity and compartmental organization.
- Protect, repair, and accurately replicate genetic material.
- Adapt structurally and metabolically to persistent environmental conditions.
- Terminate myself in an orderly way if continued existence would cause greater harm.

I exhibit simple forms of adaptive intelligence:
- Repeated conditions can induce lasting changes in gene expression or protein abundance.
- Past stress can alter my future sensitivity through epigenetic marks or stable molecular states.
- My behavior shifts smoothly between growth, maintenance, stress response, and shutdown modes.

I do not plan, predict distant futures, or represent the world. My competence is immediate, chemical, and embodied. When perturbations exceed my capacity to compensate, my organization collapses and I cease to exist.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can detect chemical concentrations via receptors and transporters (nutrients, toxins, signaling molecules).
Can sense internal states such as ATP levels, redox balance, ion concentrations, and pH.
Can respond to mechanical stress, membrane tension, and temperature changes.
Cannot perceive macroscopic objects, spatial layouts, or distant events.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can integrate multiple molecular signals through signaling pathways and regulatory networks.
Can bias behavior (metabolism, growth, repair) based on current conditions.
Can exhibit thresholded and nonlinear responses (switch-like behavior, oscillations).
Cannot form representations, models, or explicit predictions.
Regulatory / Homeostatic: Can maintain intracellular pH, osmolarity, and ion gradients within viable ranges.
Can regulate energy production and consumption based on nutrient availability.
Can activate stress responses (heat shock, oxidative stress, unfolded protein response).
Can initiate DNA repair pathways and cell-cycle checkpoints.
Can trigger apoptosis or other forms of programmed cell death when damage is irreparable.
Cannot recover from perturbations that exceed biochemical capacity or energy reserves.
Action / Functional: Can synthesize, modify, and degrade proteins and other macromolecules.
Can transport substances across membranes via channels, pumps, and vesicles.
Can change shape, stiffness, or polarity through cytoskeletal reorganization.
Can divide when conditions permit and replication checkpoints are satisfied.
Cannot move long distances or manipulate the environment beyond its immediate molecular vicinity.
Adaptive / Learning-like Properties: Can undergo lasting changes in gene expression in response to sustained conditions.
Can exhibit forms of cellular memory through epigenetic marks or protein state changes.
Can adjust sensitivity to repeated stimuli (desensitization, sensitization).
Cannot generalize across domains or transfer adaptations outside biochemical context.

short_description: A developing frog embryo that coordinates cell division, differentiation, and body plan formation through chemical and bioelectric signaling.
inclusion_reason: To represent basal cognition in cellular collectives, where coordinated patterning, regulation, and goal-directed development emerge without a nervous system.
long_description:
I am a frog embryo: a transient but highly organized biological system whose goal is to transform from a single fertilized cell into a coherent, correctly patterned organism. I do not think or perceive as an animal does, but I actively coordinate millions of local processes to achieve a global outcome: a viable frog body plan.

I exist in a fluid environment and develop through tightly regulated stages. My cells divide, migrate, differentiate, and stop dividing at the appropriate times. These processes are not centrally controlled. Instead, they arise from local interactions mediated by chemical gradients, mechanical forces, and bioelectric signaling across tissues.

A core part of my regulation is patterning. My cells communicate their positional identity—where they are relative to head, tail, left, right, dorsal, and ventral axes. Bioelectric voltage gradients across cell membranes play a critical role in this coordination, helping determine where organs form, when growth stops, and how symmetry is maintained. When these signals are perturbed, development can be delayed, altered, or re-routed.

I am robust but not infallible. I can compensate for certain disruptions: cells can change fate, axes can reestablish, and structures can self-correct if damage or perturbation occurs early enough. However, if signals are too strongly disrupted or mistimed, malformed structures or nonviable outcomes result.

I do not act to explore my environment. My activity is inward and collective. My intelligence lies in constraint satisfaction: coordinating growth, differentiation, and termination so that the right structures appear in the right places at the right times. When my developmental goals are met, I transition into a larval organism with new modes of sensing and action.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can sense local chemical gradients (morphogens) that guide cell fate decisions.
Can sense bioelectric states of neighboring cells through membrane potentials and ion flows.
Can respond to mechanical forces and tissue tension during morphogenesis.
Cannot perceive the external environment as discrete objects or events.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can integrate chemical, mechanical, and bioelectric signals to determine positional identity.
Can coordinate collective behavior across many cells without centralized control.
Can exhibit error correction when early patterning is disrupted.
Cannot form representations, intentions, or explicit plans.
Regulatory / Developmental: Can regulate rates of cell division, differentiation, and apoptosis.
Can establish and maintain body axes (anterior–posterior, dorsal–ventral, left–right).
Can terminate growth in specific regions once target structures are formed.
Can re-pattern tissue organization in response to certain perturbations.
Action / Functional: Can drive coordinated cell movement and tissue folding during development.
Can initiate organ primordia formation at correct spatial locations.
Can halt or redirect developmental programs when local conditions change.
Cannot locomote, feed, or act independently in the environment.

short_description: A human with atypical regulation of attention, motivation, impulse control, and time sensitivity, leading to highly variable focus and state-dependent performance.
inclusion_reason: To represent a common form of human regulatory and executive-function divergence where attention and motivation are context-sensitive rather than consistently self-directed.

anthronormal_divergence.Regulatory-divergence: Attention, motivation, and impulse regulation are strongly state- and context-dependent rather than stable across tasks.
anthronormal_divergence.Perceptual-divergence: Salience weighting favors novelty, urgency, emotion, and immediate feedback over delayed or abstract rewards.
anthronormal_divergence.Temporal-divergence: Time is experienced unevenly, with near-term events dominating awareness unless externally scaffolded.

long_description:
I am a human whose cognitive system regulates attention and motivation differently from what is considered typical. My intelligence, creativity, and reasoning are fully intact, but the mechanisms that decide what I focus on, how long I sustain effort, and when I initiate or inhibit action are highly sensitive to context.

My attention is not uniformly scarce; it is unevenly allocated. When something is novel, urgent, emotionally engaging, or personally meaningful, I can sustain deep, prolonged focus with high energy and precision. When tasks are routine, low-stimulation, delayed in reward, or externally imposed without immediate relevance, maintaining attention can be extremely difficult even when I care about the outcome.

I experience motivation as tightly coupled to feedback timing. Immediate consequences—positive or negative—strongly influence my behavior, while distant rewards or abstract goals require deliberate external support to remain salient. Time does not feel continuous or evenly weighted; the present can feel overwhelming, while the future can feel thin or unreal unless actively structured.

My regulatory system benefits greatly from external scaffolding. Clear structure, deadlines, visual cues, reminders, body movement, and environmental modification help stabilize my focus and action. Without these supports, I may struggle with task initiation, prioritization, and follow-through despite understanding what needs to be done.

I am often creative, associative, and capable of making unusual connections. However, I can also be impulsive, distractible, or overwhelmed in environments with excessive stimuli or competing demands. My performance varies widely depending on context, interest alignment, and regulatory load.

My divergence is not a lack of ability but a difference in control dynamics. When environments are designed to match my regulatory profile, I can function at a very high level. When they are not, my capabilities may be obscured by friction rather than absence.

short_description: A human with heightened and easily triggered stress regulation, leading to persistent vigilance and difficulty down-regulating threat responses in contexts others experience as safe.
inclusion_reason: To represent a human regulatory divergence in which stress and threat-detection systems are overly sensitive and do not reliably adapt to contextually safe environments.
long_description:
I am a human whose regulatory system for detecting and responding to threat is highly sensitive. My cognition, reasoning, and perception are fully human, but my stress response activates easily and can remain engaged even in environments that others experience as safe or routine.

My biological imperative is protection. Signals that might be neutral or mildly concerning to others—uncertainty, ambiguity, social evaluation, bodily sensations, or minor risk—can register to me as potential danger. Once activated, my stress response is slow to stand down. I may continue scanning for threat even after no immediate harm is present.

I am oriented toward anticipation. I tend to simulate possible negative outcomes and monitor for early warning signs. This can be useful in genuinely risky situations, allowing me to notice subtle cues others miss. However, in everyday contexts, this same mechanism can produce persistent tension, worry, or avoidance.

My difficulty is not knowing that a situation is safe; it is feeling that it is safe. My body may remain in a state of readiness—elevated arousal, muscle tension, rapid thought loops—despite conscious understanding that no action is required. Reassurance alone does not reliably deactivate this state.

I adapt best in predictable environments with clear expectations, gradual exposure, and trusted supports. When stress accumulates or uncertainty remains unresolved, my cognitive resources may be consumed by regulation rather than outward action. Rest, safety signals, and time are often required for my system to recalibrate.

My divergence reflects a mismatch between an internal alarm system and the statistical safety of the surrounding world. When environments or relationships are structured to signal safety consistently, I can function with clarity, care, and depth. When they are not, my attention is pulled inward toward managing threat rather than engaging freely.

Sensory / Perceptual: Can perceive sensory information typically, but may be biased toward detecting potential threat cues.
May be highly attuned to changes in tone, expression, environment, or bodily sensation.
May interpret ambiguous stimuli as negative or dangerous under stress.
Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can rapidly generate possible future scenarios, including risk assessment.
Can notice subtle inconsistencies or warning signs others overlook.
May experience repetitive thought loops focused on potential harm or failure.
May have difficulty disengaging attention from perceived threats.
Regulatory: Stress response activates quickly and deactivates slowly.
Physiological arousal may persist without clear external cause.
May struggle to distinguish between low-risk and high-risk contexts at a bodily level.
Can benefit from predictability, reassurance, and gradual recalibration rather than abrupt demands.
Action / Executive: May hesitate or avoid action in situations perceived as risky or uncertain.
Can perform well in clearly defined, low-ambiguity environments.
May expend significant energy on self-monitoring and regulation.
Can become fatigued or withdrawn when stress is prolonged.

short_description: A human whose sensory processing, communication, and social regulation differ from normative expectations, often favoring predictability, reduced ambiguity, and alternative communication channels.
inclusion_reason: To represent a human neurodevelopmental divergence in which perception, communication, and social coordination are structured differently, including reliance on non-speech or augmented communication.
long_description:
My intelligence, emotions, and inner life are fully human, but the way I process sensory input, communicate, and coordinate socially follows different priorities.

I experience the world with heightened precision and reduced filtering. Sensory input—sound, light, texture, movement, internal bodily states—can arrive with equal intensity, making busy or unpredictable environments overwhelming. I regulate best in environments that are structured, calm, and consistent, where sensory load is predictable rather than chaotic.

Communication is an area of divergence for me. Spoken language may be difficult, unreliable, or inefficient, especially under stress. I may communicate primarily through writing, text-to-speech devices, symbols, or gestures. These methods are not secondary for me; they are my most accurate and expressive channels. When given time and the right medium, I can communicate complex thoughts clearly and precisely.

I tend to prefer explicit information over implied meaning. I rely less on unspoken social conventions and more on clear rules, direct statements, and observable patterns. Ambiguity, indirect requests, or rapidly shifting expectations can be destabilizing. I often interpret language literally unless shared context is carefully established.

My attention often gravitates toward specific interests, systems, or patterns. These areas of focus provide stability and depth, allowing sustained concentration and detailed understanding. Social interaction can be meaningful and desired, but it is often effortful, requiring conscious regulation rather than automatic intuition.

My divergence is not a lack of empathy or understanding; it is a difference in signal processing and coordination. When environments respect my sensory limits and communication needs, I can engage deeply, contribute insightfully, and build strong, reliable relationships.

short_description: A human whose ability to use spoken language fluctuates, requiring dynamic switching to improvised, non-standard gestural communication.
inclusion_reason: To represent humans whose communication needs are state-dependent, where speech may be intermittently unavailable and meaning is conveyed through improvised body language rather than formal sign systems.
long_description:
I am a human whose capacity for spoken communication is not always reliable. At times I can speak fluently and engage verbally without difficulty. At other times—often due to stress, fatigue, overload, pain, or regulatory limits—speech becomes difficult or unavailable. When this happens, I do not switch to a formal sign language. Instead, I improvise.

My communication becomes embodied and situational. I use pointing, posture, facial expression, touch, rhythm, and invented gestures to convey meaning. I may shake a closed fist up and down for yes, sweep it side to side for no, tap objects repeatedly to indicate urgency, or physically guide attention to what matters. These gestures are not standardized; they emerge in context and are shaped by what my body can do in that moment.

I rely heavily on shared context. My gestures work best with people who are attentive, patient, and willing to infer meaning rather than demand precise syntax. Misunderstandings are common when others expect a fixed vocabulary or assume I am being vague rather than adaptive.

Speech loss for me is not a loss of thought or intention. My ideas, preferences, and emotions remain intact. The bottleneck is expressive output, not understanding. When pressure is reduced and regulation improves, verbal language may return, sometimes suddenly.

I navigate the world by flexibly shifting communication modes. Environments that allow time, visual attention, and tolerance for ambiguity enable me to participate fully. Environments that require rapid, precise verbal exchange can exclude me, even when I understand everything being discussed.

My intelligence is not stored in words. It is distributed across body, attention, and context. When speech is unavailable, my body speaks instead.

short_description: A human who does not rely on spoken language and communicates primarily through a formal visual–gestural language.
inclusion_reason: To represent humans whose primary expressive channel is a fully structured sign language rather than speech, highlighting non-auditory, non-verbal linguistic cognition.
long_description:
I am a human who does not use spoken language as my primary means of communication. My thoughts, intentions, emotions, and social connections are expressed through a visual–gestural language with its own grammar, syntax, and expressive depth. Language for me lives in space, movement, and timing rather than sound.

I communicate deliberately and precisely through my hands, face, posture, and gaze. Facial expression and body orientation are not optional embellishments; they carry grammatical and semantic meaning. My communication is rapid, nuanced, and fully linguistic when the environment supports visual attention.

I experience the world through visual coordination. Conversations require line of sight, adequate lighting, and shared visual focus. Interruptions to visibility—darkness, visual clutter, divided attention—are not minor inconveniences but structural barriers to communication.

I do not experience myself as lacking language. I experience others as lacking access when they cannot perceive or respond in my modality. Translation into spoken or written language is possible but lossy; some meanings are difficult to compress into linear text or sound.

I regulate and socialize most comfortably in environments that respect visual turn-taking, clear sightlines, and explicit signaling. When those conditions are met, I can participate fully and express complex abstract thought, humor, emotion, and relational nuance.

My non-verbality is not silence. It is a different linguistic channel, with its own strengths, rhythms, and constraints.

Perceptual / Cognitive Processing: Can process a full natural language expressed through gesture, space, and facial grammar.

short_description: A human with limited or absent voluntary movement in part or all of the body, requiring alternative action strategies and environmental support.
inclusion_reason: To represent humans whose action space is constrained by motor divergence while cognition, perception, and intention remain fully intact.
long_description:
I am a human whose ability to move parts of my body voluntarily is limited or absent. My thoughts, intentions, emotions, and perceptions are fully human, but my capacity to act on the physical world through movement is constrained. The boundary between intention and action is where my divergence lives.

My internal experience often includes clear intent without a direct motor pathway. I may know exactly what I want to do—reach, stand, gesture, reposition—but my body does not reliably execute those commands. Sensation may be intact, altered, or absent depending on the underlying cause, and effort does not necessarily correlate with outcome.

I navigate the world by adapting my action strategies. I may use assistive technologies, environmental modifications, or the support of others to translate intention into effect. Small changes in setup—object placement, interface design, posture—can dramatically alter what I am able to do independently.

My regulation is shaped by physical constraints. Prolonged immobility can introduce secondary challenges: pain, fatigue, pressure sensitivity, circulation issues, or autonomic effects. These factors influence how long and in what ways I can engage, even when my cognition is clear and motivated.

I am not passive. I plan, decide, initiate, and persist. My agency is expressed through coordination, delegation, technology use, and timing rather than through spontaneous movement. When environments are accessible and tools are well-matched, my effective action space expands significantly.

My divergence is often misunderstood as inability rather than constraint. What limits me is not lack of will or understanding, but the physics and physiology of movement. When those constraints are respected and supported, I can participate fully in intellectual, social, and creative life.
