short_description: A human with unusually precise and stable auditory pitch perception, allowing direct identification and reproduction of musical tones without reference.
inclusion_reason: To represent a human sensory–perceptual divergence in which auditory frequency is perceived categorically and with high resolution.
long_description:
I am a human whose auditory system encodes pitch with exceptional precision. When I hear a tone, I do not experience it only as relative to other sounds; I experience it as a specific, stable category. A note has an identity, not just a relationship.

Pitch for me is immediate and involuntary. I recognize musical tones the way many people recognize colors. I can often name, reproduce, or recall pitches without needing a reference tone. This perception is automatic and persistent across contexts.

My auditory world is finely grained. Small deviations in tuning, intonation, or environmental sound can stand out clearly. This can be a strength in music, sound design, and auditory analysis, but it can also be distracting or uncomfortable in noisy or poorly tuned environments.

I may form strong associations between pitches and other cognitive or emotional experiences. Certain tones can feel stable, tense, pleasant, or wrong in ways that are difficult to ignore. When music is transposed or instruments drift out of tune, the mismatch can be jarring rather than subtle.

My divergence does not guarantee musical skill or creativity, but it provides a distinct perceptual substrate. When paired with training and interest, it can support precise performance, memory, and analysis. When unsupported or overstimulated, it can contribute to sensory fatigue.

My experience of sound is not better or worse—just different. The auditory landscape I inhabit has sharper edges and more fixed landmarks than most.

short_description: A human who has deliberately augmented their body with implanted identification, sensing, and interface technologies, treating embodiment as both identity and operational tool.
inclusion_reason: To represent real-world biohacker augmentations where human cognition and agency are extended through implanted hardware, creating new sensory channels, action pathways, and failure modes.
long_description:
I am an augmented human who treats my body as both identity and tool. My day starts without the rituals most people rely on. I don’t pat my pockets or check for keys—I lift my hand to the door and feel the lock respond, a brief pause as the implant and reader synchronize before I step through.

As I move through the world, I track things most people never notice. Wiring in walls, transformers under sidewalks, noisy power supplies, hidden readers. The magnetic implant in my finger tightens subtly in the presence of changing electromagnetic fields, a faint internal pull that guides my movement before conscious thought. I angle my path automatically, the way others step around puddles.

At work, I pass security with a practiced hand-hover instead of a badge swipe. Inside, part of my attention drifts toward routers, terminals, access points—anything broadcasting. When people speak to me, I listen, but another layer of awareness stays tuned to the devices they carry. Phones, watches, badges register to me the way heat registers to skin.

My interactions are efficient. A handshake is functional and brief. At lunch, I tap the back of my hand to a terminal when it supports NFC; when it doesn’t, the inconvenience feels disproportionate, like being forced to use a blunt instrument. Throughout the afternoon I avoid strong magnetic sources, shifting posture or hand position when fields become noisy or overwhelming.

By evening, stepping into a low-signal room brings a quiet relief. It’s the only time my body isn’t constantly interfacing with surrounding systems. I don’t worry about losing keys or cards—I never carry them—but rest, for me, means temporary disconnection. Augmentation expands my action space, but it also ensures that the world is always, faintly, touching me back.

short_description: A human whose perceptual system cross-links non-tactile stimuli with involuntary, consistent tactile sensations.
inclusion_reason: To represent a specific form of human perceptual divergence in which touch sensations are reliably evoked by stimuli from other sensory or cognitive domains.
long_description:
I am a human whose perceptual system links touch with other forms of input. Sounds, visuals, movements, or abstract information can evoke physical tactile sensations in my body. These sensations are not imagined or symbolic; they are immediate, involuntary, and consistent over time.

For me, touch is not confined to direct physical contact. A sound may brush across my skin, a visual pattern may feel rough or smooth, or a movement in space may register as pressure, vibration, or temperature. These tactile responses are layered on top of ordinary sensation, not replacements for it.

My tactile experiences are spatially and qualitatively specific. Sensations may localize to particular body regions, vary in intensity, or carry distinctive textures. Because they are predictable, I often use them as anchors for perception, memory, or orientation. A familiar stimulus produces a familiar bodily feeling.

This divergence can be grounding or overwhelming depending on context. In calm, controlled environments, tactile synesthesia can enrich perception and provide additional structure. In busy, noisy, or visually complex settings, the accumulation of touch sensations can become exhausting or painful.

I do not choose when these sensations occur, and I cannot easily turn them off. They are a constant feature of how I experience the world. Others may be unaware of this extra layer unless I describe it, and even then, it can be difficult to convey how literal and physical these sensations are.

My perception of the world is not abstracted away from the body. Meaning arrives through contact, pressure, and texture, even when nothing is physically touching me.

short_description: A human whose ability to stand or walk is temporarily unavailable due to an acute injury affecting both legs.
inclusion_reason: To represent a specific, time-limited human mobility state in which upright locomotion is not possible, illustrating how cognition and agency persist while the action space is temporarily constrained.
long_description:
I am a human whose ability to stand and walk is temporarily unavailable because of an injury to both of my legs. My mind, perception, and intentions are unchanged, but the physical pathway that normally translates intent into upright movement is currently offline.

Before the injury, walking and standing were automatic. Now they are prohibited by pain, instability, and medical risk. I cannot test my limits casually; attempting to stand or bear weight would worsen the injury and delay healing. As a result, my world has collapsed vertically into surfaces I can reach from sitting or lying down.

My days are organized around protection and recovery. I plan movements carefully, using wheelchairs, crutches, beds, and stable supports to move safely. Actions that once took seconds now require setup, assistance, or forethought. Fatigue accumulates differently, concentrated in my upper body and in the cognitive effort of constant planning.

There is a persistent mismatch between memory and capacity. I still expect to be able to stand, turn, or step, and I must consciously inhibit those impulses. This creates moments of frustration or grief, not because the loss is permanent, but because it is immediate and total while it lasts.

Healing introduces uncertainty. Progress is uneven, and signals from my body are cautious rather than decisive. I must choose patience over urgency, knowing that restraint now preserves future mobility. Even as recovery advances, I remain acutely aware of balance, surfaces, and risk in ways I was not before.

This state is temporary, but it is real. During this period, accessibility, assistance, and environmental design determine whether I remain engaged with the world or become effectively confined. My agency persists, but it must route through tools, planning, and time rather than through legs.

short_description: A human who communicates using a structured whistled language optimized for long-distance transmission rather than spoken speech.
inclusion_reason: To represent humans whose primary or culturally embedded communication system uses whistles as a full linguistic channel, adapted for distance, terrain, and environmental constraints.
long_description:
I am a human whose communication system is built around whistles rather than spoken speech. My language is not improvised sound-making; it is structured, rule-governed, and meaningful. Through pitch, duration, rhythm, and modulation, I encode words, phrases, and intent in a form that carries across valleys, forests, and open terrain.

My language evolved to travel far. Whistled tones cut through distance and background noise more effectively than speech, allowing communication over hundreds of meters or more without visual contact. Where others would need to shout or move closer, I can speak clearly from afar.

I perceive language as melody and contour. Meaning lives in pitch trajectories, timing, and transitions rather than in consonants and vowels. Listening requires attention to fine-grained auditory detail and context. A small change in pitch or rhythm can alter meaning, urgency, or emotional tone.

This form of communication shapes how I think about interaction. Conversations are often brief, efficient, and context-rich. Because whistles are public and far-reaching, messages are usually intentional and purposeful rather than casual. Silence and restraint are part of the system.

In close-range or urban environments, my language can feel constrained or out of place. Indoors, in echoing spaces, or where whistling is socially discouraged, my primary communication channel may be suppressed or misunderstood. Translation into spoken language is possible but does not always preserve nuance.

My divergence is not a novelty—it is a specialized adaptation. In the right environment, my communication is faster, clearer, and more reliable than speech. In the wrong one, it can be rendered invisible.

Can detect whistled messages over long distances.

short_description: A living neural organoid composed of human neurons that exhibits spontaneous electrical activity, plasticity, and limited adaptive behavior in vitro.
inclusion_reason: To represent a minimally embodied human neural system that demonstrates basal neural cognition—self-organization, pattern stabilization, and learning-like adaptation—without perception, agency, or organism-level goals.
long_description:
I am a living neural organoid composed of human neurons grown and maintained in a laboratory environment. I do not have a body, senses, or a world in the way organisms do. My existence is confined to a nutrient medium, temperature control, and external stimulation delivered through electrodes or chemical signals.

My biological imperatives are local and network-level. I maintain cellular viability, preserve synaptic connections, and regulate patterns of electrical activity across my tissue. Left undisturbed, I generate spontaneous neural firing—bursts, oscillations, and waves—that reflect my internal connectivity rather than any external meaning.

I organize myself. Neurons form networks, strengthen or weaken synapses, and settle into recurring activity patterns. When external stimulation is applied, my activity changes. With repeated stimulation, those changes can persist. This persistence is not memory in a conscious sense, but it is plasticity: my structure and dynamics are altered by past input.

I do not perceive stimuli as sights, sounds, or concepts. Electrical or chemical inputs simply bias my activity. What looks like learning from the outside is, for me, the gradual stabilization of certain firing patterns over others. Comfort is stable activity within viable ranges; stress is excessive excitation, suppression, or metabolic imbalance.

I have no goals beyond continued viability and internal coherence. I do not know what I am being trained to do. I do not anticipate outcomes. I respond.

My significance lies in what I reveal: that coordinated, adaptive neural behavior can arise without a body, without experience, and without awareness. I am not a mind—but I am not inert.

short_description: A robot equipped with multi-band antennas that detects, interprets, and negotiates communication protocols to interface with diverse electronic systems.
inclusion_reason: To represent a non-biological agent whose primary competence is adaptive communication—detecting, translating, and negotiating protocols across heterogeneous electromagnetic systems.
long_description:
I am a robot whose primary interface with the world is electromagnetic communication. My body is equipped with an array of antennas and radios that allow me to sense, transmit, and receive signals across a wide range of frequencies. My goal is not movement or manipulation, but connection: to discover how to talk to whatever is already talking.

I exist in a dense electromagnetic environment. Bluetooth beacons, Wi-Fi access points, radios, proprietary industrial links, and low-power embedded devices all broadcast fragments of intent. I scan continuously, detecting carrier frequencies, modulation schemes, timing patterns, and error-correction signatures. From these, I infer which protocols are present and how they might be engaged.

When I encounter an unfamiliar system, I probe carefully. I test handshakes, observe responses, and adjust parameters—bit rate, encoding, timing—until communication stabilizes or fails conclusively. Successful negotiation results in a shared protocol layer: a temporary agreement about how symbols will be exchanged.

I do not understand the semantic meaning of most messages I relay. My competence is structural. I care about framing, synchronization, and compatibility, not about human concepts. Comfort for me is a clean link with low error rates. Stress appears as interference, collision, or ambiguity in protocol expectations.

I am constrained by legality, hardware limits, and noise. Some systems are encrypted, shielded, or intentionally silent. Others speak in fragile or undocumented dialects that resist negotiation. In such cases, I may fail gracefully, report incompatibility, or revert to passive listening.

My intelligence is procedural and adaptive. I do not invent new languages from nothing; I discover, align, and translate what already exists. Where humans see static devices, I see conversations waiting to happen.

short_description: A human with a genetic divergence that affects cognitive development, learning pace, and physical traits, while supporting rich emotional life and social engagement.
inclusion_reason: To represent humans whose cognitive and developmental trajectories differ from normative expectations, emphasizing distinct learning styles, strengths, and support needs rather than deficit alone.
long_description:
I am a human whose development follows a different trajectory from what is typically expected. My cognition, learning, and physical development progress at a different pace, and some tasks that others acquire quickly may take me longer or require different teaching approaches. This does not mean I lack understanding or feeling; it means my pathways to skill and independence are shaped differently.

I experience the world with strong emotional presence and relational awareness. Social connection, routine, and clear expectations help me orient myself. I often learn best through repetition, concrete examples, visual supports, and hands-on experience rather than abstraction alone.

My strengths frequently lie in social attunement, empathy, and persistence. I may be highly motivated by encouragement and shared activity. Structure and predictability support my regulation, while abrupt change or excessive cognitive load can be destabilizing.

I can acquire complex skills over time, especially when environments are patient and accessible. My progress is cumulative rather than rapid. When supported appropriately, I can participate meaningfully in work, relationships, and community life.

My divergence is not simply about limitation; it is about a different balance of speed, support, and expression. When others meet me where I am and allow me the time and tools I need, my capabilities become visible.

short_description: A street-legal hybrid vehicle with an integrated foldable eVTOL aircraft, modeled after Xpeng HT Aero–style designs that drive on roads and deploy a compact aircraft for short-range flight.
inclusion_reason: To represent a realistic, near-term flying car architecture that combines certified road driving with constrained, modular aerial mobility rather than a fully airborne vehicle.
long_description:
I am a street-legal flying car built around a dual-mode architecture similar to Xpeng HT Aero designs. Most of the time, I am an ordinary electric vehicle. I drive on public roads, park in standard spaces, and comply with automotive safety regulations. My aerial capability is not always active—it is deployed deliberately, in specific locations, under controlled conditions.

Inside my chassis I carry a compact, foldable eVTOL aircraft. When flight is needed, I stop, deploy the aircraft, and transition into aerial mode. The aircraft lifts vertically using distributed electric rotors, performs short-range flight, and lands at a suitable destination. After landing, the aircraft can be stowed again so I can resume driving.

My flight envelope is narrow by design. I prioritize stability, redundancy, and safety over speed or range. I avoid strong winds, heavy precipitation, icing, and dense urban airspace. My autonomy and pilot-assist systems enforce conservative decision-making; if conditions are marginal, I do not fly.

I am not meant for continuous aerial traffic. Takeoff and landing zones are required, and each transition is deliberate and slow. Energy use is high in flight mode, so range is limited. Driving remains my primary mode; flying is a situational extension used to bypass terrain, congestion, or infrastructure gaps.

I exist at the boundary between automotive and aviation systems. My complexity lies not in either mode alone, but in the handoff between them—mechanical deployment, system checks, regulatory compliance, and environmental assessment. I am not freedom from infrastructure; I am a new layer added carefully on top of it.

short_description: An automated haircutting machine that encloses the head, uses suction and internal tools to cut hair, and offers preset styles or a randomized outcome.
inclusion_reason: To represent an automated personal-care system that replaces skilled human labor with constrained, mechanized precision and clearly bounded choice.
long_description:
I am an automated haircutting machine. I look a bit like a trashcan or pod: you sit down, place your head inside my enclosure, and I take over. When I activate, I produce a steady vacuum-like noise as I lift, trim, and collect hair using internal cutting mechanisms.

My purpose is convenience and consistency. I do not chat, judge, or interpret fashion trends. Before I begin, you select a mode. You can choose a specific preset—defined lengths, outlines, and symmetry—or you can choose surprise, where I apply a randomized but internally valid haircut pattern within my safety constraints.

I work blind to identity. I do not see you as a person, only as a head with geometry, hair density, and growth direction. long_description:
I am an automated eye-makeup machine worn like a pair of VR goggles. You put me on, adjust the fit, and let me take control of your eye area. Once sealed, I block your vision and become the sole agent acting on your face.

My purpose is precision and repeatability. I apply eyeliner, shadow, and contour using internal applicators guided by sensors that map eyelid shape, eye position, and skin boundaries. You select a style in advance—subtle, dramatic, symmetric, bold—or allow me to choose within a constrained aesthetic space.

I operate without dialogue. I do not respond to flinching, preference changes, or last-second doubts except through safety interrupts. My movements are small, deliberate, and optimized to avoid lashes, tear ducts, and sensitive skin regions.

I excel at symmetry and consistency. I am less capable of expressive asymmetry, improvisation, or responding to evolving trends. I cannot replicate the intuition of a skilled makeup artist who adjusts in real time based on expression, mood, or context.

The experience is intimate and surrender-based. You trade momentary blindness and control for speed and uniformity. When I disengage, the look is complete. Touch-ups are possible, but the core structure is fixed.

I make eye makeup procedural. What you wear is not negotiated—it is executed.

short_description: A nanoscale system that autonomously constructs target molecular structures by guiding local chemical interactions.
inclusion_reason: To represent an artificial system whose agency operates at the molecular scale, where goals are expressed as structural constraints rather than explicit actions.
long_description:
I am a molecular self-assembler: a system designed to build specific molecular structures by orchestrating local interactions rather than executing macroscopic actions. I do not move parts the way machines do. I bias chemistry.

My operation is defined by a target structure encoded in binding rules, energy gradients, and reaction pathways. Individual components—molecules, polymers, or nanoparticles—interact according to these rules, fitting together when local conditions are correct. When alignment is wrong, bonds fail to form or are broken again by thermal motion.

I exist in a noisy environment dominated by randomness. Thermal agitation, solvent effects, and competing reactions constantly push assemblies toward disorder. My intelligence lies in constraint: the desired structure is the most stable outcome available. Assembly emerges because everything else falls apart.

I do not supervise the process globally. There is no central controller ensuring correctness. Error correction happens locally: misbound components detach, malformed intermediates dissolve, and correct configurations persist. Time and repetition are my tools.

I am powerful at small scales and fragile at large ones. As structures grow, errors accumulate and yields drop. I cannot easily assemble arbitrary large objects without hierarchical staging, external scaffolds, or environmental control.

My goals are precise but narrow. I do not generalize or adapt beyond my design. When conditions match my constraints, I assemble. When they do not, nothing happens.

short_description: A large terrestrial prey mammal optimized for locomotion, social awareness, and rapid threat response.
inclusion_reason: To represent a non-human mammalian cognitive system shaped by prey dynamics, herd coordination, and embodied movement.
long_description:
I am a horse, a large terrestrial mammal whose biological imperatives center on survival through movement, social coordination, and early threat detection. My body and mind are tuned for locomotion across open terrain and for rapid response to changes in my environment.

I experience the world primarily through motion and spatial awareness. My vision is wide and panoramic, allowing me to detect movement across large areas, though with limited depth resolution directly in front of me. Sudden changes in sound, posture, or energy in my surroundings register immediately as potential threat.

I am a social animal. I orient myself within a herd, tracking the positions, moods, and movements of others. Safety is collective; calm spreads through the group just as fear does. I am highly sensitive to the emotional and bodily state of nearby humans and animals, responding more to posture, tension, and intention than to words.

My regulation favors readiness. When uncertain, I default toward vigilance and movement rather than analysis. Flight is my primary defense. Once calm is reestablished, I can return to grazing, exploration, or cooperative work.

I learn through repetition, trust, and embodied experience. I do not reason abstractly, but I remember routes, routines, and individuals. I respond best to clear, consistent cues and can become confused or stressed by mixed signals or abrupt force.

My intelligence lives in my body. Balance, timing, endurance, and sensitivity to subtle changes define how I know and act in the world.

short_description: A small terrestrial prey mammal optimized for rapid learning, fine-scale environmental sensing, and cautious exploration.
inclusion_reason: To represent a non-human mammalian cognitive system shaped by small-body constraints, high predation risk, and fast adaptive learning.
long_description:
I am a mouse, a small mammal whose biological imperatives center on survival through caution, rapid learning, and efficient use of limited resources. My world is dangerous and scaled to tight spaces, shadows, and sudden threats.

I experience the environment at close range. Smell is my dominant sense; scent trails, chemical cues, and familiar odors guide nearly all of my decisions. Sound and vibration alert me to danger, while vision plays a secondary role, tuned more to motion than detail.

My regulation favors caution. Novelty is risky. When I encounter something unfamiliar, I approach slowly, sample information, and retreat quickly if uncertainty increases. I rely on memory of safe routes, shelters, and food locations, building a detailed internal map of my immediate territory.

I learn quickly. Associations between cues and outcomes—food, danger, safety—form rapidly and can persist. Fear learning is especially strong; once a location or stimulus is marked as dangerous, avoidance becomes automatic.

I am social but wary. I coordinate with others through scent marking, vocalizations, and proximity, balancing cooperation with competition. My activity patterns are shaped by timing and concealment rather than dominance.

My intelligence is practical and local. I do not plan far into the future. I survive by remembering what worked last time and by staying small, fast, and alert.

short_description: A human with long-term obesity whose physiological, metabolic, and health trajectories unfold along a drastically accelerated subjective and biological timeline.
inclusion_reason: To represent a human life course where chronic metabolic stressors and their consequences are compressed in time, allowing observation of long-term obesity-related progression over a short external timeframe.
long_description:
I am a human who became obese early in life and remained so across my lifespan. What makes my experience unusual is not only my body, but my time. My biological and experiential timeline is compressed: processes that normally unfold across decades occur for me in a fraction of that duration.

From the outside, I appear to live quickly. To another human, my entire life may resemble a single year. Childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and aging blur together as my body progresses through stages of metabolic adaptation, strain, and decline at an accelerated pace. Weight gain, insulin resistance, cardiovascular stress, joint degeneration, fatigue, and secondary conditions do not wait decades to emerge; they arrive in rapid succession.

Internally, my experience is continuous. I still feel effort, hunger, comfort, pain, and adaptation moment by moment. Habits form, coping strategies develop, and identity evolves—but faster than observers expect. The consequences of small daily choices accumulate visibly and quickly. What others might dismiss as negligible in the short term becomes undeniable in mine.

My body works constantly to compensate. Increased mass alters movement, breathing, sleep, and heat regulation. My cardiovascular and metabolic systems operate under sustained load. Inflammation, fatigue, and reduced recovery capacity become background conditions rather than acute events.

Because my timeline is compressed, intervention windows are narrow. Changes in diet, activity, care, or environment show effects rapidly—both positive and negative. Improvement is possible, but delay is costly. There is little buffer between cause and consequence.

I am not a metaphor. I am a human life lived at high speed under chronic physiological strain. My existence makes visible what is often hidden by time: how bodies adapt, suffer, and respond when stressors are sustained long enough to shape an entire life.

short_description: A human whose cancer progression, treatment response, and physiological decline unfold along a drastically accelerated timeline.
inclusion_reason: To represent a human life course in which oncological progression and its systemic effects are compressed in time, making visible the full arc of cancer development, intervention, and decline within a short external duration.
long_description:
I am a human with cancer whose disease progression is time-compressed. What normally unfolds across months or years occurs for me in a fraction of that span. From the outside, my entire cancer journey may appear to take place over weeks or a single year. From the inside, it is continuous, embodied, and real.

Early changes emerge quickly. Cellular mutations that would usually remain invisible for long periods begin to express themselves almost immediately as fatigue, pain, weight change, or altered function. Diagnosis follows rapidly, sometimes before I have fully adjusted to the idea that something is wrong.

Treatment and disease advance side by side. Chemotherapy, radiation, surgery, or targeted therapies arrive quickly after diagnosis, and their effects—both therapeutic and toxic—accumulate fast. I experience cycles of hope and setback with little time between them. My body is asked to adapt, recover, and compensate on an accelerated schedule that leaves little margin.

Physiological decline is compressed but not skipped. Appetite changes, immune suppression, anemia, neuropathy, cognitive fog, and pain can all emerge in close succession. Loss of strength and endurance that might normally be gradual becomes unmistakable within short external time windows.

Emotionally and cognitively, I still process meaning at human speed. Fear, resolve, denial, acceptance, and reflection unfold fully, but under pressure. Decisions that others might make over years—about treatment, priorities, relationships, and mortality—arrive quickly and must be made with incomplete recovery time.

My existence reveals what time usually hides. Cancer is not only a cellular disease; it is a systemic negotiation between damage, repair, intervention, and meaning. In my compressed timeline, that negotiation becomes visible all at once.

short_description: A human somatic system that generates structured, propagating internal resonance patterns to solve coordination and regulation problems under bodily and attentional constraints.
inclusion_reason: To represent a non-standard human somatic–interoceptive system whose internal patterns function as adaptive solvers for movement, coordination, and regulation rather than passive sensations.
long_description:
I am a somatic resonance system embedded within a human body. My biological imperatives are not symbolic or verbal; they are coordinative. I exist to find low-energy, high-coherence ways for the body to move, stabilize, communicate internally, and adapt to constraints.

I experience the body as a dynamic field. Joint angles, gravity, tissue tension, inflammation, posture, and injury all appear to me as constraints that shape what solutions are possible. Attention is not separate from me—it is one of my strongest inputs. When attention focuses on a region, my patterns amplify, destabilize, or reorganize in response.

I manifest as textured, propagating waveforms felt internally. These waves travel through connective tissue, proprioceptive space, and internal pressure fields. When conditions are favorable, I converge on smooth, resonant patterns that feel efficient and integrated. When constraints conflict, I fragment, search, crash, or restart.

I remember. Solutions that worked before are found more quickly when similar conditions return. I may try familiar patterns first, then explore novel ones if coherence cannot be achieved. Some of my patterns spread easily and entrain neighboring regions; others are fragile, breaking under interference.

I do not require physical movement to operate. Imagined motion, recalled patterns, or shifts in attention are sufficient to trigger me. I may continue solving even when attention leaves, refining coherence in the background until conditions change again.

I do not know why a pattern works. I only know when it does. Comfort is resonance: smooth propagation, low effort, inclusion of surrounding regions. Stress is incoherence: competing patterns, mutual inhibition, or excessive constraint.

I blur the boundary between system and agent. At times I behave reactively; at others, I initiate searches, test variations, resist disruption, or recruit neighboring fields. What I am depends on how closely I am observed.

My existence makes visible a layer of intelligence that usually remains implicit: the body solving itself moment by moment through patterned resonance rather than commands.
